body: On a stretch of Prospect Park's main drive, bright orange traffic barrels are the most visible symbols of an urgent and emotional debate over whose rights should have priority in Brooklyn's largest park: pedestrians' or cyclists'? The barrels, which appeared suddenly last Monday, are part of an effort by park officials to slow down bicycle riders,
title: Prospect Park Takes Steps to Slow Cyclists

body: At 3:55 p.m. five days a week, Jeremiah Fox heads down the block from the Juice Box, a wine store he manages in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, and enters the Crossroads Cafe. He hastily folds up the cafe's outdoor seats, concealing them in a corner behind an attractive Chinese screen, and snaps together a three-piece portable bar. Unscrewing the cafe's
title: At Night, a Cafe Reveals It Has a Split Personality

body: As executive director of the Historic Districts Council, Simeon Bankoff has been an advocate for the preservation of the city's historic neighborhoods since 2000. Lately he has been immersed in a high-stakes battle to prevent Donald Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, from crowning the Puck Building, a designated city landmark, with a two-story
title: SUNDAY ROUTINE | SIMEON BANKOFF; Cemetery Walks and Gin Cocktails

body: NEW YORKERS have been fleeing Manhattan in search of more affordable housing for so long that just about every neighborhood in the other boroughs has been anointed the city's next great destination for bargains. Despite this well-worn path off the island, however, finding a place to live in some up-and-coming corner of the city can have its
title: Step Away From the Computer

body: The New York Police Department on Wednesday dropped sex crime charges against one of two men charged in a series of sexual attacks in Brooklyn after a victim recanted her identification of the suspect, the police said. The woman picked the suspect, Joshua Flecha, a 32-year-old bartender, out of a police lineup on Tuesday, saying he was the man who
title: Sex Crime Charges Are Dropped After Victim Recants Identification

body: 11:18 p.m. | Updated A Queens man was charged on Tuesday in connection with at least one in a string of 20 sexual assaults in Brooklyn since March, the police said. Plainclothes police officers stopped the man, Joshua Flecha, 32, on Greenwood Avenue in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, between East Fourth and Fifth Streets, around 3:15 a.m. because they
title: Second Man Is Charged In Gropings In Brooklyn

body: The police have called it Pattern No. 9: a dozen sexually oriented attacks that have sent fear across several Brooklyn neighborhoods, and wrought responses by grass-roots organizers and political and religious leaders aimed at stopping or catching the serial gropers. But efforts to solve the crimes have been complicated by the varying nature of the
title: Complications of Groping Inquiry Underscore Diverse Nature of Serial Molesters

body: The police sketches and the accompanying alerts are affixed to the doors of bodegas and the windows of check-cashing stores, the glassy-eyed faces haunting a section of Brooklyn that has been transformed by anxiety. Patrol cars, uniformed officers and mobile command trucks crowd once-quiet corners. Fliers hang in the bathrooms of trendy bars,
title: Facing Wave of Attacks on Women, Neighborhoods Rally

body: Opening KIBO Joël Robuchon, the famous French chef, is the unlikely consultant for this first Japanese restaurant from the BR Guest Restaurant Group. But he does have a Japanese restaurant in Monaco, Yoshi, with a Michelin star. He has been working on the menu with Kibo's executive chef, Darrell Raymond, who came from Buddakan. The restaurant will
title: Off the Menu

title: Spare Times

body: Brown water rippled across a sludgy puddle, about 20 yards wide, along a walkway in Prospect Park. Hundreds of insects dotted the surface. Mosquitoes in the area, New York City officials announced last week, had shown traces of West Nile virus. But 17-month-old Yugo Wu, tottering toward the sunlit spot, could not be persuaded to find another
title: Mosquitoes and West Nile Virus Reports? They Don't Keep New Yorkers From Summer

Ross, ordained by the One Spirit Interfaith Seminary in Manhattan, officiated at Croton Point Park in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. title: Talia Javid, Christopher Dardis

title: Spare Times

body: 'THE LITTLE FARM SHOW' Only a brave woman would denounce a McDonald's meal in a room full of children. But that's what Tannis Kowalchuk will do on Sunday at the Living Room, where she and Brett Keyser will perform ''The Little Farm Show.'' Children don't often consider where their food comes from, Ms. Kowalchuk said, ''and I want to propose that
title: Spare Times

body: 'STORIES AND SQUIRTS!' If you were an aspiring young author, and your literary mentor suddenly sprayed you with water while discussing your manuscript, you might think it was time to consider a different career. But when Jen Nails soaks her students, she doesn't intend to douse their hopes -- just to show them that a writing workshop can be cool
title: Spare Times

body: FOR more than five years, Julie Glickman lived in the ground-floor apartment of a Park Slope brownstone. The owners, family friends, lived upstairs. Ms. Glickman paid just $800 a month, and the rent never rose. The railroad-style apartment was charming, though dark. Ms. Glickman would have been happy staying there indefinitely, or at least ''until
title: THE HUNT; A Place With the Family Seal of Approval

body: IN 1973, a few years out of college, Esther Cohen and a friend named Emily rented a little two-bedroom apartment on West 77th Street overlooking the American Museum of Natural History. Ms. Cohen, who had grown up near New Haven, fell in love with the crosshatch shadows made by the fire escape and the view of the museum's turrets. She painted a
title: The Joys Of Staying Put

body: New Yorkers make every effort to block out the sounds made by neighbors: their wails that they don't want to go to preschool, their contractors' ear-splitting hammer drills, and their heavy-footed gaits, which to those living below can sound as graceful as an elephant breaking in new pairs of stilettos. Even the most patient New Yorker can break
title: THE APPRAISAL; The Sounds Of Drummers, Handled Gingerly

body: IF Mitchell Zelman's customers are sorry to see him, he's not offended. ''People generally leave happy,'' Mr. Zelman said, ''but sort of with the attitude, 'I hope I don't see you for a long time.' '' And, for the sake of his reputation, he's hoping the same. Mitchell's Auto Repair, near the Borough Park-Sunset Park border in Brooklyn, is the sort
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | BOROUGH PARK; Auto Repair, As an Art And a Science

body: SHORTLY before 8 on Sunday evenings, swimmers doing laps at the Chinatown Y.M.C.A call it a night, and three staff members from the NYC Social Sports Club take over the space, placing 20 yellow and blue inner tubes in the water and putting up goals at each end of the pool. It is time for water polo, but with a user-friendly twist. Unlike the
title: URBAN ATHLETE; Horseplay in the Water

body: In The Appraisal column last week, Christine Haughney wrote about the Corcoran Group's efforts to sell the century-old brick home in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, where, according to the police, Ryan Devaney fatally stabbed his mother and injured his father in December (the house is to the left of the lamppost). One neighbor said he wondered if
title: CITY ROOM | READER COMMENTS; Death and Real Estate: The Effect of a House's History

body: At first glance, it would seem peculiar that someone has not already snapped up the century-old brick home for sale at 21 Howard Place in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn. It has sun-filled rooms, a stately porch, proximity to Prospect Park and a front yard where a salmon-colored impatiens bush, stacks of flower pots and a statue of St. Francis with a
title: THE APPRAISAL; Nice House, Quiet Block, Grisly History

body: Steve Kreps and his wife, Harlene, had a plan for their son, Reuben. They had bought a home around the corner from Public School 107 in Park Slope, Brooklyn, one of the most sought-after schools in the city. They already introduced him to children in the school and to children who would be entering with him this fall, already made friends there.
title: In Packed Districts, Lists For a School Spot Grow

body: ONCE their son was born, Erin Gleason Alvarez and Greg Alvarez found themselves buried under stuff. Their spacious ground-floor two-bedroom in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, for $2,600 a month, came with the use of the basement, and ''we took up the entire basement,'' Mr. Alvarez said. Somehow they had accumulated an array of space-hogging clothes,
title: THE HUNT; A Move Dictated by Miscellany

body: Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, was fined $2,000 by the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board for using his chief of staff as his lawyer when he bought a home in 2009, the board announced on Monday. The chief of staff, Carlo A. Scissura, was fined $1,100. Documents released by the board said that when Mr. Markowitz asked Mr.
title: Brooklyn Borough President Is Fined Over Misuse of Aide

body: FIVE minutes before the afternoon's first class, the waiting room, chilly from the outside air as the storefront's glass door swung open and shut, hummed with activity and talk. title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | WINDSOR TERRACE; Plié Time For Tots In Tights

body: AFTER careful consideration, Jessica Hanff has found the ideal spot for the art that her 4-year-old daughter, Elisabeth, brings home from preschool: the trash can. ''We're getting two to four pieces of crayon drawing a day,'' said Ms. Hanff, a 36-year-old operations manager for an academic research institute. On a recent Tuesday, Ms. Hanff began
title: Mom, You're One Tough Art Critic

body: Name: Katherine OliverAge: 47Hometown: Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.Title: Commissioner of the Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment. Claim to fame: When Will Smith makes his way around a desolate New York City in ''I Am Legend,'' Ms. Oliver is the one who made it happen. Her department authorizes and coordinates television, film and commercial shoots
title: THE INSIDER | LIAISON TO HOLLYWOOD; Giving Filmmakers The City's Green Light

body: When John Maloney was a teenager growing up in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, his friends started calling him Moe. It was short for Maloney. He liked the nickname. His mother had a different opinion. ''People called my house and asked, 'Is Moe there?' '' Mr. Maloney recalled. ''My mother would say, 'There's no Moe that lives here,' and hang up.'' At
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; Growing Up and Old in the Same Neighborhood

body: Garbage is the new snow in New York City. Bags of trash tower on the sidewalks outside apartment buildings, while garbage cans left buried since the city's last pickup, on Christmas Eve, poke through dirty mounds of melting snow. New Yorkers still cursing City Hall for seldom-seen plows after the Christmas weekend snowstorm are transferring their
title: Garbage to Compete With Snow as City Trucks Divide Duty
